title: 115_hr1535
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook Wild and Scenic River Act". The findings are also included in the Act. The Congress finds that the Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook have significant natural, cultural, and recreational resources, supporting their potential inclusion in the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. The Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook Management Plan, June 2011, establishes objectives, standards, and action programs for long-term protection without Federal management of affected lands not owned by the United States. The Wild and Scenic Study Committee has voted in favor of Wild and Scenic River designation, with strong local support from all ten communities abutting the study area. The State of Connecticut General Assembly has endorsed the designation of the Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook as components of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. The Rainbow Dam and Reservoir are located outside the designated river segments and are deemed compatible with the Wild and Scenic River designation. The Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook have been designated as part of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System by the State of Connecticut General Assembly. The Rainbow Dam and Reservoir, located outside the designated river segments, are considered compatible with the Wild and Scenic River designation. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act is amended to include the Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook in Connecticut, totaling approximately 62 miles. The segments will be administered by the Secretary of the Interior as recreational rivers. The Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook in Connecticut, totaling approximately 62 miles, will be designated as recreational rivers under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. This includes specific segments of Salmon Brook, such as the main stem, West Branch, and East Branch, ranging from 2.4 to 12.6 miles in length. The Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook in Connecticut, totaling approximately 62 miles, will be designated as recreational rivers under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. This includes specific segments of Salmon Brook, such as the main stem, West Branch, and East Branch, ranging from 2.4 to 12.6 miles in length. SEC. 4. MANAGEMENT. The Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook Wild and Scenic Committee, along with the Secretary, will lead and coordinate the implementation of the management plan for the designated river segments. The Secretary is authorized to enter into cooperative agreements for the protection and enhancement of these river segments. The Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook Wild and Scenic Committee, along with the Secretary, will lead and coordinate the implementation of the management plan for the designated river segments. Cooperative agreements may be entered into with the State of Connecticut, specific towns, and local organizations for consistent land management, including financial assistance from the United States. Zoning ordinances in the designated river segments' towns will be considered. The designated river segments in Connecticut, including Burlington, East Granby, Farmington, Granby, Hartland, Simsbury, and Windsor, will satisfy the standards of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. Federal acquisition of lands by condemnation is prohibited for these segments, with the Secretary's authority limited to acquisition by donation or other means. The Act limits land acquisition to donation or with owner consent, subject to management plan criteria. The designation does not affect licensing or operation of Rainbow Dam and Reservoir. The Lower Farmington River is not part of the National Park System and is not subject to its regulations. The protection afforded to designated river segments cannot be changed administratively by the National Park Service. SEC. 5. Farmington River, Connecticut, designation revision. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act is amended to change the length of the river and its endpoint. SEC. 6. Definitions. Defines "management plan" and "Secretary" for the purposes of the Act.
